result.execSummary:
The defendant Everett P Stoddard was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Criminal Damage to Property [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse, Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.01(1).
  • Battery [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse, Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Jackson County Clerk of Circuit Court

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation now serving.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Pay the costs of supervision.  DNA sample and surcharge not ordered.
Obtain and maintain employment, acceptable to his agent.
Defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant is to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.
Defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located. 

Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, with the victim or her residence.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  

Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Submit to domestic violence and mental heath assessments and comply with any recommendations.

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Poss.  Parties have the revocation packet.  Page 2 typo noted by defense.  Completion date of Farham should be 2016.  State recommended:   2 months jail on count 2, and 9 months jail on count 3.  Consecutive.  115 days credit.  Defense recommended: 2  months jail on count 2, and 8 months jail on count 3.  Concurrent.  115 days credit.  Court ordered: 90 days jail on count 2, and 9 months jail on count 3.  Concurrent.  Judgment for unpaid court ordered financial obligations.  115 days credit.
Faxed to Judge Goodman's office.  JMM

records.descr: Notice of court ordered financial obligations

records.addlTxt: ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Fredrickson.  Joint recommendation:  Defendant will plead guilty to counts  2 & 3.  Counts 1 and 4 to be dismissed and read in.   2 yr. probation.  No contact with victim.  No alcohol.  DV programming.  Mental health evaluation.  Plus any other recommended treatment and counseling.  Victim notification complied with.  No response received. Defendant plead guilty to Counts 2 and 3.  Court advised the defendant of the charge and possible penalties he plead to.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, elements and constitutional rights with the defendant.  Repeater status confirmed.  Defense stipulated to a factual basis for the plea.  Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived his constitutional rights and entered his plea.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of Counts 2 and 3.   Counts 1 and 4 dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes.   Defendant did not elect to exercise his right to allocution.  Court ordered: sentence withheld,  2 years probation. Concurrent.   No contact with the victim or her residence.  Obtain and maintain employment acceptable to his agent.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  AODA and comply with recommended treatment and counseling.    Domestic violence assessment and comply with recommended programing.  Mental heath assessment and comply with recommended programming.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  CC. DNA surcharge not ordered.   Pay the costs of supervision.

records.descr: Application for specific judicial assign approved

records.addlTxt: Reading of information waived.  Defendant stood mute.  NGP entered.

ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody and with Attorney Fredrickson.  Form filed with court.  Court questioned defendant on his understanding of the waiver.  Defendant understood the waiver.  Court found defendant knowingly and intelligently waived his right to preliminary hearing.  Information filed with court.

ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, and with Attorney Fredrickson.  Plea started.  Victim notification complied with, according to State.    Joint recommendation for 2 years probation with conditions.  Court questions probation recommendation.  Court not accepting joint recommendation.  Schedule for WOPH.  8/17/15 at 3:45 pm

Pre-trial conference at 07-15-2015 10:00 am.
Status conference at 08-03-2015 03:00 pm.

Pre-trial conference at 07-15-2015 10:00 am.
Status conference at 08-03-2015 11:00 am.

Court questioned defendant on his understanding of waiving the time limits for preliminary hearing.  Court finds defendant knowingly and intelligently waiving time limits for preliminary hearing..  Track misdemeanor counts.  PTC & STC dates set.
records.descr: Waiver of time limits for preliminary hearing

records.addlTxt: ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant appeared by video from the jail.  Attorney Fredrickson appeared in court.  Reading of complaint waived.

Defendant appeared by video from Jackson County Jail with no attorney present.  ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant admits to receipt of complaint.  Court reviews charges/potential penalties.  He states he understands and that he talked to SPDO and they will be representing him.  SPD Paul Fredrickson present in courtroom - he states he will probably be appointed.  Set for initial appearance on 6-22-15 at 9:30.  DA requests a $5000 signature bond with conditions.  Court ordered bond as requested.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Until further order of the court, you shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, except through your attorney, with any of the following individuals and/or businesses:  Dory S., minor child, and Chad H.
